When all this had been pleasantly settled , [Caspian]85-caspian ordered horses , of which there were a few in [the castle]561-the castle , though very ill - groomed and [he]85-caspian , with [Bern]101-bern and [Drinian]98-drinian and [a few others]611-a few others , rode out into [the town]541-the town and made for [the slave market]613-the slave market . “ [Your]125-pug life is forfeit , [Pug]125-pug , for laying hands on [[our]2130-our royal person]2131-our royal person yesterday , ”[85-caspian] said [Caspian]85-caspian . “ But [your]125-pug ignorance is pardoned . “ [That dear little gel]2135-that dear little gel and [the nice young gentleman]2136-the nice young gentleman ? ”[125-pug] said [Pug]125-pug with an ingratiating smile . “ Why , [they]629-they were snapped up at once — ”[125-pug]

“ [We]2130-our ’re here , [we]2130-our ’re here , [Caspian]85-caspian , ”[80-lucy] cried [Lucy]80-lucy and [Edmund]79-edmund together and , “ At [your]85-caspian service , [Sire]1874-sire , ”[89-reepicheep] piped [Reepicheep]89-reepicheep from [another corner]628-another corner . [Two merchants of Calormen]633-two merchants of calormen at once approached . [The Calormen]32-calormen have dark faces and long beards . “ That is only fair , [sirs]2138-sirs , ”[85-caspian] said [Caspian]85-caspian . “ [Every man who has bought [a slave today]2140-a slave today]2139-every man who has bought a slave today must have [his]2139-every man who has bought a slave today money back . “ Does [[your]125-pug good Majesty]2142-your good majesty mean to beggar [me]125-pug ? ”[125-pug] whined [Pug]125-pug .

“ [You]125-pug have lived on broken hearts all [your]125-pug life , ”[85-caspian] said [Caspian]85-caspian , “ and if [you]125-pug are beggared , it is better to be [a beggar]2143-a beggar than [a slave]2144-a slave . But where is [[my]85-caspian other friend]2145-my other friend ? ”[85-caspian]

“ Oh [him]2145-my other friend ? ”[125-pug] said [Pug]125-pug . “ Oh take [him]2145-my other friend and welcome . Glad to have [him]2145-my other friend off [my]125-pug hands . [I]125-pug ’ve never seen such a drug in the market in all [my]125-pug born days . Priced [him]2145-my other friend at five crescents in the end and even so nobody’d have [him]2145-my other friend . Threw [him]2145-my other friend in free with other lots and still [no one]1909-no one would have [him]2145-my other friend . Would n’t touch [him]2145-my other friend . Would n’t look at [him]2145-my other friend . ’ [Packs]132-packs , bring out [Sulky]133-sulky . ”[125-pug]

Thus [Eustace]73-eustace was produced , and sulky [he]73-eustace certainly looked ; for though [no one]1909-no one would want to be sold as [a slave]2144-a slave , it is perhaps even more galling to be a sort of utility slave whom [no one]1909-no one will buy . [He]640-i walked up to [Caspian]85-caspian and said , “ [I]640-i see . As usual . Been enjoying [yourself]85-caspian somewhere while the rest of [us]641-they were [prisoners]2147-prisoners . [I]640-i suppose [you]85-caspian have n’t even found out about the British Consul . Of course not . ”[640-i]

That night [they]641-they had a great feast in [the castle of [Narrowhaven]26-narrowhaven]642-the castle of narrowhaven and then , “ Tomorrow for the beginning of [our]641-they real adventures ! ”[89-reepicheep] said [Reepicheep]89-reepicheep when [he]89-reepicheep had made [his]89-reepicheep bows to [everyone]251-everyone and went to bed . But it could not really be tomorrow or anything like it . For now [they]641-they were preparing to leave [all known lands]644-all known lands and [seas]645-seas behind [them]641-they and the fullest preparations had to be made . [The Dawn Treader]382-the dawn treader was emptied and drawn on [land]395-land by eight horses over rollers and every bit of [her]382-the dawn treader was gone over by [the most skilled shipwrights]648-the most skilled shipwrights . Then [she]382-the dawn treader was launched again and victualled and watered as full as [she]382-the dawn treader could hold — that is to say for twenty - eight days . Even this , as [Edmund]79-edmund noticed with disappointment , only gave [them]641-they a fortnight ’s eastward sailing before [they]641-they had to abandon [their]641-they quest .

While all this was being done [Caspian]85-caspian missed no chance of questioning [all the oldest sea captains whom [he]85-caspian could find in [Narrowhaven]26-narrowhaven]649-all the oldest sea captains whom he could find in narrowhaven to learn if [they]649-all the oldest sea captains whom he could find in narrowhaven had any knowledge or even any rumours of [land further to the east]650-land further to the east . [He]85-caspian poured out many a flagon of the castle ale to [weather - beaten men with short grey beards and clear blue eyes]651-weather - beaten men with short grey beards and clear blue eyes , and many a tall yarn [he]85-caspian heard in return . But [those who seemed the most truthful]652-those who seemed the most truthful could tell of [no lands beyond [the Lone Islands]7-the lone islands]653-no lands beyond the lone islands , and [many]621-many thought that if [you]655-you sailed too far east [you]655-you would come into the surges of [a sea without lands that swirled perpetually round the rim of the world—“And that , [I]621-many reckon , is where [[your]655-you Majesty ’s friends]2149-your majesty ’s friends went to the bottom]2148-a sea without lands that swirled perpetually round the rim of the world—“and that , i reckon , is where your majesty ’s friends went to the bottom . ”[621-many] The rest had only wild stories of islands inhabited by [headless men]656-headless men , [floating islands]657-floating islands , waterspouts , and a fire that burned along [the water]1834-the water . Only one , to [Reepicheep]89-reepicheep ’s delight , said , “ And beyond that , [Aslan country]2150-aslan country . But that ’s beyond [the end of [the world]1877-the world]2151-the end of the world and [you]655-you ca n’t get there . ”[659-they] But when [they]659-they questioned — [him]89-reepicheep [he]89-reepicheep could only say that [he]89-reepicheep ’d heard it from [[his]89-reepicheep father]198-his father .

[Bern]101-bern could only tell [them]659-they that [he]89-reepicheep had seen [[his]89-reepicheep six companions]661-his six companions sail away eastward and that nothing had , ever been heard of [them]661-his six companions again . [He]89-reepicheep said this when [he]89-reepicheep and [Caspian]85-caspian were standing on [the highest point of [Avra]23-avra]662-the highest point of avra looking down on [the eastern ocean]663-the eastern ocean . “ [I]1894-the duke ’ve often been up here of a morning , ”[1894-the duke] said [the Duke]1894-the duke , “ ands seen the sun come up out of [the sea]250-the sea , and sometimes it looked as if it were only a couple of miles away . And [I]1894-the duke ’ve wondered about [[my]1894-the duke friends]2134-my friends and wondered what there really is behind that horizon . Nothing , most likely , yet [I]1894-the duke am always half ashamed that [I]1894-the duke stayed behind . But [I]1894-the duke wish [[your]1894-the duke Majesty]1838-your majesty would n’t go . [We]2156-we may need [your]1894-the duke help here . This closing [the slave market]613-the slave market might make [a new world]2158-a new world ; war with [Calormen]32-calormen is what [I]1894-the duke foresee . [[My]1894-the duke liege]2024-my liege , think again . ”[1894-the duke]

“ [I]85-caspian have an oath , [[my]85-caspian lord]1993-my lord [Duke]134-duke , ”[85-caspian] said [Caspian]85-caspian . “ And anyway , what could [I]85-caspian say to [Reepicheep]89-reepicheep ? ”[85-caspian]

IT was nearly three weeks after [[their]665-their landing]666-their landing that [the Dawn Treader]109-the dawn treader was towed out of [Narrowhaven harbour]667-narrowhaven harbour . Very solemn farewells had been spoken and [a great crowd]617-a great crowd had assembled to see [her]109-the dawn treader departure . There had been cheers , and tears too , when [Caspian]85-caspian made [his]85-caspian last speech to [the Lone Islanders]107-the lone islanders and parted from [the Duke]1894-the duke and [[his]1894-the duke family]670-his family , but as [the ship]234-the ship , [her]234-the ship purple sail still flapping idly , drew further from [the shore]455-the shore , and the sound of [Caspian]85-caspian ’s trumpet from the poop came fainter across [the water]1834-the water , [everyone]251-everyone became silent . Then [she]109-the dawn treader came into the wind . The sail swelled out , [the tug]675-the tug cast off and began rowing back , the first real wave ran up under the Dawn Treader ’s prow , and [she]109-the dawn treader was [a live ship]676-a live ship again . [The men off duty]677-the men off duty went below , [Drinian]98-drinian took the first watch on the poop , and [she]109-the dawn treader turned [her]109-the dawn treader head eastward round [the south of [Avra]23-avra]2067-the south of avra .

The next few days were delightful . [Lucy]80-lucy thought [she]80-lucy was [the most fortunate girl in [the world]1877-the world]679-the most fortunate girl in the world ; as [she]80-lucy woke each morning to see the reflections of the sunlit water dancing on the ceiling of [[her]80-lucy cabin]681-her cabin and looked round on all the nice new things [she]80-lucy had got in [the Lone Islands]7-the lone islands — seaboots and buskins and cloaks and jerkins and scarves . And then [she]80-lucy would go on [deck]334-deck and take a look from the forecastle at [a sea]683-a sea which was a brighter blue each morning and drink in an air that was a little warmer day by day . After that came breakfast and such an appetite as one only has at [sea]1854-sea .

[She]80-lucy spent a good deal of time sitting on the little bench in the stern playing chess with [Reepicheep]89-reepicheep . It was amusing to see [him]89-reepicheep lifting the pieces , which were far too big for [him]89-reepicheep , with both paws and standing on tiptoes if [he]89-reepicheep made a move near the centre of the board . [He]89-reepicheep was [a good player]685-a good player and when [he]89-reepicheep remembered what [he]89-reepicheep was doing [he]89-reepicheep usually won . But every now and then [Lucy]80-lucy won because [the Mouse]458-the mouse did something quite ridiculous like sending [a knight]1957-a knight into the danger of [a queen]688-a queen and castle combined . This happened because [he]89-reepicheep had momentarily forgotten it was a game of chess and was thinking of a real battle and making [the knight]689-the knight do what [he]89-reepicheep would certainly have done in its place . For [his]89-reepicheep mind was full of forlorn hopes , death - or - glory charges , and last stands .

But this pleasant time did not last . There came an evening when [Lucy]80-lucy , gazing idly astern at the long furrow or wake [they]690-them were leaving behind [them]690-them , saw a great rack of clouds building itself up in the west with amazing speed .

Then a gap was torn in it and a yellow sunset poured through the gap . All the waves behind [them]690-them seemed to take on unusual shapes and [the sea]250-the sea was a drab or yellowish colour like dirty canvas . The air grew cold . [The ship]234-the ship seemed to move uneasily as if [she]80-lucy felt danger behind [he]89-reepicheep The sail would be flat and limp one minute and wildly the next . While [she]80-lucy was noting these things and wondering at a sinister change which had come over the very noise the wind , [Drinian]98-drinian cried , “ All hands on [deck]334-deck . ”[98-drinian] In a moment [everyone]251-everyone became frantically busy . The hatches wet battened down , the galley fire was put out , [men]694-men went aloft to reef the sail . Before [they]694-men had finished the storm struck [them]694-men . It seemed to [Lucy]80-lucy that [a great valley in [the sea]250-the sea]695-a great valley in the sea opened just before [their]694-men bows , and [they]694-men rushed down in it , deeper down than [she]80-lucy would have believed possible . A great grey hill of water , far higher than the mast , rushed to meet [them]694-men ; it looked certain death but [they]694-men were tossed to the top of it . Then [the ship]234-the ship seemed to spin round . A cataract of water poured over [the deck]255-the deck ; the poop and forecastle were like two islands with [a fierce sea between [them]694-men]699-a fierce sea between them . aloft [the sailors]275-the sailors were lying out along [the yard]701-the yard desperate trying to get control of the sail . A broken rope stood out sideways in the wind as straight and stiff as if it was poker .

“ Get below , [Ma’am]2162-ma’am , ”[98-drinian] bawled [Drinian]98-drinian . And [Lucy]80-lucy knowing that [landsmen]702-landsmen — and [landswomen]703-landswomen — are a nuisance to [the crew]704-the crew , began to obey . It was not easy . The Dawn Treader was listing terribly to starboard and [the deck]255-the deck sloped like the roof of [a house]706-a house . [She]80-lucy had to clamber round to the top of the ladder , holding on to the rail , and the stand by while [two men]707-two men climbed up it , and then get down as best [she]80-lucy could . It was well [she]80-lucy was already holding tight for at the foot of the ladder another wave roar across [the deck]255-the deck , up to [her]80-lucy shoulders . [She]80-lucy was already almost wet through with spray and rain but this was colder . Then [she]80-lucy made a dash for [the cabin]287-the cabin door and got in and shut out for a moment the appalling sight of the speed with which [they]275-the sailors were rushing into the dark , but not of course the horrible confusion of creakings , groanings , snappings , clatterings , roarings and boomings which only sounded more alarming below than [they]275-the sailors had done on the poop .

And all next day and all the next it went on . It went on till [one]256-one could hardly even remember a time before it had begun . And there always had to be [three men at the tiller]711-three men at the tiller and it was as much as three could do to keep any kind of a course . And there always had to be [men at the pump]712-men at the pump . And there was hardly any rest for [anyone]1930-anyone , and nothing could be cooked and nothing could be dried , and [one man]714-one man was lost overboard , and [they]275-the sailors never saw the sun .

When it was over [Eustace]73-eustace made the following entry in [his]73-eustace diary .

“ 3 September . The first day for ages when [I]73-eustace have been able to write . [We]2163-we had been driven before a hurricane for thirteen days and nights . [I]73-eustace know that because [I]73-eustace kept a careful count , though the others all say it was only twelve . Pleasant to be embarked on a dangerous voyage with [people who ca n’t even count right]2164-people who ca n’t even count right ! [I]73-eustace have had a ghastly time , up and down enormous waves hour after hour , usually wet to the skin , and not even an attempt at giving [us]2163-we proper meals . Needless to say there ’s no wireless or even a rocket , so no chance of signalling [anyone]1930-anyone for help . It all proves what [I]73-eustace keep on telling [them]275-the sailors , the madness of setting out in [a rotten little tub like this]2166-a rotten little tub like this . It would be bad enough even if one was with [decent people]2167-decent people instead of [fiends in human form]2168-fiends in human form . [Caspian]85-caspian and [Edmund]79-edmund are simply brutal to [me]73-eustace . The night [we]2163-we lost [our]2163-we mast ( there ’s only a stump left now ) , though [I]73-eustace was not at all well , [they]275-the sailors forced [me]73-eustace to come on [deck]334-deck and work like [a slave]2144-a slave . [Lucy]80-lucy shoved [her]80-lucy oar in by saying that [Reepicheep]89-reepicheep was longing to go only [he]89-reepicheep was too small . [I]73-eustace wonder [she]80-lucy does n’t see that everything that little beast does is all for the sake of showing off . Even at [her]80-lucy age [she]80-lucy ought to have that amount of sense . Today [the beastly boat]2171-the beastly boat is level at last and the sun ’s out and [we]2163-we have all been jawing about what to do . [We]2163-we have food enough , pretty beastly stuff most of it , to last for sixteen days . ( [The poultry]2172-the poultry were all washed overboard . Even if [they]2172-the poultry had n’t been , the storm would have stopped [them]2172-the poultry laying . ) The real trouble is water . Two casks seem to have got a leak knocked in them and are empty . ( [Narnian]4-narnian efficiency again . ) On short rations , half a pint a day each , [we]2163-we ’ve got enough for twelve days . ( There ’s still lots of rum and wine but even [they]275-the sailors realize that would only make [them]275-the sailors thirstier . )[73-eustace]

“ If [we]2163-we could , of course , the sensible thing would be to turn west at once and make for [the Lone Islands]7-the lone islands . But it took [us]2163-we eighteen days to get where [we]2163-we are , running like mad with a gale behind [us]2163-we . Even if [we]2163-we got an east wind it might take [us]2163-we far longer to get back . And at present there ’s no sign of an east wind — in fact there ’s no wind at all . As for rowing back , it would take far too long and [Caspian]85-caspian says [the men]2173-the men could n’t row on half a pint of water a day . [I]2174-i ’m pretty sure this is wrong . [I]2174-i tried to explain that perspiration really cools [people]207-people down , so [the men]2173-the men would need less water if [they]2173-the men were working . [He]85-caspian did n’t take any notice of this , which is always [his]85-caspian way when [he]85-caspian ca n’t think of an answer . [The others]1949-the others all voted for going on in the hope of finding [land]395-land . [I]2174-i felt it [my]2174-i duty to point out that [we]2163-we did n’t know there was [any land ahead]2179-any land ahead and tried to get [them]1949-the others to see the dangers of wishful thinking . Instead of producing a better plan [they]1949-the others had the cheek to ask [me]2174-i what [I]2174-i proposed . So [I]2174-i just explained coolly and quietly that [I]2174-i had been kidnapped and brought away on this idiotic voyage without [my]2174-i consent , and it was hardly [my]2174-i business to get [them]1949-the others out of [their]1949-the others scrape .[2201-two dozen ”]

“ 4 September . Still becalmed . Very short rations for dinner and [I]73-eustace got less than [anyone]1930-anyone . [Caspian]85-caspian is very clever at helping and thinks [I]73-eustace do n’t see ! [Lucy]80-lucy for some reason tried to make up to [me]73-eustace by offering [me]73-eustace some of [hers]80-lucy but that [interfering prig Edmund]79-edmund would n’t let [her]80-lucy . Pretty hot sun . Terribly thirsty all evening .[73-eustace]

“ 5 September . Still becalmed and very hot . Feeling rotten all day and am sure [I]73-eustace ’ve got a temperature . Of course [they]1949-the others have n’t the sense to keep a thermometer on board .[2201-two dozen ”]

“ 6 September . A horrible day . Woke up in the night knowing [I]73-eustace was feverish and must have a drink of water . [Any doctor]2181-any doctor would have said so . [Heaven]135-heaven knows [I]73-eustace ’m [the last person]2182-the last person to try to get any unfair advantage but [I]73-eustace never dreamed that this water - rationing would be meant to apply to [a sick man]2183-a sick man . In fact [I]73-eustace would have woken [the others]1949-the others up and asked for some only [I]73-eustace thought it would be selfish to wake [them]1949-the others . So [I]73-eustace got up and took [my]73-eustace cup and tiptoed out of [the Black Hole]2185-the black hole [we]2186-we slept in , taking great care not to disturb [Caspian]85-caspian and [Edmund]79-edmund , for [they]1949-the others ’ve been sleeping badly since the heat and the short water began . [I]73-eustace always try to consider [others]2187-others whether [they]2187-others are nice to [me]73-eustace or not . [I]73-eustace got out all right into [the big room]2188-the big room , if [you]2189-you can call it [a room]2190-a room , where the rowing benches and the luggage are . The thing of water is at this end . All was going beautifully , but before [I]73-eustace ’d drawn a cupful who should catch [me]73-eustace but that little spy [Reep]120-reep . [I]73-eustace tried to explain that [I]73-eustace was going on [deck]334-deck for a breath of air ( the business about the water had nothing to do with [him]120-reep ) and [he]120-reep asked [me]73-eustace why [I]73-eustace had a cup . [He]120-reep made such a noise that [the whole ship]2192-the whole ship was roused . [They]2192-the whole ship treated [me]73-eustace scandalously . [I]73-eustace asked , as [I]73-eustace think [anyone]1930-anyone would have , why [Reepicheep]89-reepicheep was sneaking about the water cask in the middle of the night . [He]89-reepicheep said that as [he]89-reepicheep was too small to be any use on [deck]334-deck , [he]89-reepicheep did sentry over the water every night so that [one more man]2195-one more man could go to sleep . Now comes [their]2192-the whole ship rotten unfairness : [they]2192-the whole ship all believed [him]89-reepicheep . Can [you]2196-you beat it ?[73-eustace]

“ [I]73-eustace had to apologize or [the dangerous little brute]2197-the dangerous little brute would have been at [me]73-eustace with [his]2197-the dangerous little brute sword . And then [Caspian]85-caspian showed up in [his]85-caspian true colours as [a brutal tyrant]2198-a brutal tyrant and said out loud for [everyone]251-everyone to hear that [anyone]1930-anyone found “[2201-two dozen ”] stealing ” water in future would “[73-eustace] get [two dozen ”]2201-two dozen ” . [I]73-eustace did n’t know what this meant till [Edmund]79-edmund explained to [me]73-eustace . It comes in the sort of books [those Pevensie kids]2202-those pevensie kids read .[73-eustace]

“ After this cowardly threat [Caspian]85-caspian changed [his]85-caspian tune and started being patronizing . Said [he]85-caspian was sorry for [me]2201-two dozen ” and that [everyone]251-everyone felt just as feverish as [I]2201-two dozen ” did and [we]2204-we must all make the best of it , etc . , etc . Odious stuck - up prig . Stayed in bed all day today .[2201-two dozen ”]

“ 7 September . A little wind today but still from the west .[73-eustace]

Made a few miles eastward with part of the sail , set on what [Drinian]98-drinian calls the jury - mast - that means the bowsprit set upright and tied ( [they]715-they call it “ lashed ”[715-they] ) to the stump of the real mast . Still terribly thirsty .

“ 8 September . Still sailing east . [I]2201-two dozen ” stay in [my]2201-two dozen ” bunk all day now and see [no one]1909-no one except [Lucy]80-lucy till [the two fiends]2206-the two fiends come to bed . [Lucy]80-lucy gives [me]2201-two dozen ” a little of [her]80-lucy water ration . [She]80-lucy says [girls]2207-girls do n’t get as thirsty as [boys]2208-boys . [I]2201-two dozen ” had often thought this but it ought to be more generally known at [sea]1854-sea .[2201-two dozen ”]

“ 9 September . Land in sight ; [a very high mountain a long way off to the south - east]2210-a very high mountain a long way off to the south - east .[73-eustace]

“ 10 September . [The mountain]2211-the mountain is bigger and clearer but still a long way off . [Gulls]136-gulls again today for the first time since [I]2201-two dozen ” do n’t know how long .[2201-two dozen ”]

“ 11 September . Caught some fish and had them for dinner . Dropped anchor at about 7 p.m. in three fathoms of water in [a bay of [this mountainous island]2213-this mountainous island]2212-a bay of this mountainous island . That idiot [Caspian]85-caspian would n’t let [us]716-us go [ashore]537-ashore because it was getting dark and [he]85-caspian was afraid of savages and wild beasts . Extra water ration tonight . ”[73-eustace]

What awaited [them]716-us on [this island]717-this island was going to concern [Eustace]73-eustace more than [anyone else]1978-anyone else , but it can not be told in [his]73-eustace words because after September 11 [he]73-eustace forgot about keeping [his]73-eustace diary for a long time .

When morning came , with a low , grey sky but very hot , [the adventurers]719-the adventurers found [they]719-the adventurers were in [a bay encircled by such cliffs and crags that it was like [a Norwegian fjord]721-a norwegian fjord]720-a bay encircled by such cliffs and crags that it was like a norwegian fjord . In front of [them]719-the adventurers , at [the head of [the bay]521-the bay]722-the head of the bay , there was [some level land]724-some level land heavily overgrown with trees that appeared to be cedars , through which a rapid stream came out . Beyond that was a steep ascent ending in a jagged ridge and behind that a vague darkness of mountains which ran into dull - coloured clouds so that [you]725-you could not see [their]726-their tops . The nearer cliffs , at [each side of [the bay]521-the bay]727-each side of the bay , were streaked here and there with lines of white which [everyone]251-everyone knew to be waterfalls , though at that distance [they]726-their did not show any movement or make any noise . Indeed [the whole place]730-the whole place was very silent and the water of [the bay]521-the bay as smooth as glass . It reflected every detail of [the cliffs]732-the cliffs . The scene would have been pretty in a picture but was rather oppressive in real life . It was [not [a country]734-a country that welcomed [visitors]210-visitors]733-not a country that welcomed visitors .

[The whole ship ’s company]736-the whole ship ’s company went ashore in two boatloads and [everyone]251-everyone drank and washed deliciously in [the river]738-the river and had a meal and a rest before [Caspian]85-caspian sent [four men]739-four men back to keep [the ship]234-the ship , and the day ’s work began . There was everything to be done . The casks must be brought ashore and the faulty ones mended if possible and all refilled ; a tree — a pine if [they]739-four men could get it — must be felled and made into a new mast ; sails must be repaired ; a hunting party organized to shoot any game [the land]500-the land might yield ; clothes to be washed and mended ; and countless small breakages on board to be set right . For [the Dawn Treader]109-the dawn treader [herself]109-the dawn treader — and this was more obvious now that [they]739-four men saw [her]109-the dawn treader at a distance — could hardly be recognized as [the same gallant ship which had left [Narrowhaven]26-narrowhaven]742-the same gallant ship which had left narrowhaven . [She]109-the dawn treader looked [a crippled , discoloured hulk which [anyone]1930-anyone might have taken for a wreck]743-a crippled , discoloured hulk which anyone might have taken for a wreck . And [[her]109-the dawn treader officers and [crew]746-crew]745-her officers and crew were no better — lean , pale , red - eyed from lack of sleep , and dressed in rags .

As [Eustace]73-eustace lay under a tree and heard all these plans being discussed [his]73-eustace heart sank . Was there going to be no rest ? It looked as if [their]739-four men first day on [the longed - for land]747-the longed - for land was going to be quite as hard work as a day at [sea]1854-sea . Then a delightful idea occurred to [him]73-eustace . [Nobody]749-nobody was looking [they]739-four men were all chattering about [[their]739-four men ship]750-their ship as if [they]739-four men actually liked the beastly thing . Why should n’t [he]73-eustace simply slip away ? [He]73-eustace would take a stroll inland , find [a cool , airy place up in [the mountains]752-the mountains]751-a cool , airy place up in the mountains , have a good long sleep , and not rejoin [the others]1949-the others till the day ’s work was over . [He]73-eustace felt it would do [him]73-eustace good . But [he]73-eustace would take great care to keep [the bay]521-the bay and [the ship]234-the ship in sight so as to be sure of [his]73-eustace way back . [He]73-eustace would n’t like to be left behind in [this country]756-this country .

[He]73-eustace at once put [his]73-eustace plan into action . [He]73-eustace rose quietly from [his]73-eustace place and walked away among the trees , taking care to go slowly and in an aimless manner so that [anyone who saw [him]73-eustace]757-anyone who saw him would think [he]73-eustace was merely stretching [his]73-eustace legs . [He]73-eustace was surprised to find how quickly the noise of conversation died away behind hiin and how very silent and warm and dark green [the wood]758-the wood became . Soon [he]73-eustace felt [he]73-eustace could venture on a quicker and more determined stride .

This soon brought [him]73-eustace out of [the wood]758-the wood . The ground began sloping steeply up in front of [him]73-eustace . The grass was dry and slippery but manageable if [he]73-eustace used [his]73-eustace hands as well as [his]73-eustace feet , and though [he]73-eustace panted and mopped [his]73-eustace forehead a good deal , [he]73-eustace plugged away steadily . This showed , by the way , that [his]73-eustace new life , little as [he]73-eustace suspected it , had already done [him]73-eustace some good ; [the old Eustace]73-eustace , [Harold]75-harold and [[Alberta]76-alberta ’s [Eustace]73-eustace]760-alberta ’s eustace , would have given up the climb after about ten minutes .

Slowly , and with several rests , [he]73-eustace reached [the ridge]430-the ridge . Here [he]73-eustace had expected to have a view into [the heart of [the island]763-the island]762-the heart of the island , but the clouds had now come lower and nearer and a sea of fog was rolling to meet [him]73-eustace . [He]73-eustace sat down and looked back . [He]73-eustace was now so high that [the bay]521-the bay looked small beneath [him]73-eustace and miles of [sea]1854-sea were visible . Then the fog from [the mountains]752-the mountains closed in all round [him]73-eustace , thick but not cold , and [he]73-eustace lay down and turned this way and that to find the most comfortable position to enjoy [himself]73-eustace .

But [he]73-eustace did n’t enjoy [himself]73-eustace , or not for very long . [He]73-eustace began , almost for the first time in [his]73-eustace life , to feel lonely . At first this feeling grew very gradually . And then [he]73-eustace began to worry about the time . There was not the slightest sound . Suddenly it occurred to [him]73-eustace that [he]73-eustace might have been lying there for hours . Perhaps [the others]1949-the others had gone ! Perhaps [they]1949-the others had let [him]73-eustace wander away on purpose simply in order to leave [him]73-eustace behind ! [He]73-eustace leaped up in a panic and began the descent .

At first [he]73-eustace tried to do it too quickly , slipped on the steep grass , and slid for several feet . Then [he]73-eustace thought this had carried [him]73-eustace too far to the left — and as [he]73-eustace came up [he]73-eustace had seen precipices on that side . So [he]73-eustace clambered up again , as near as [he]73-eustace could guess to the place [he]73-eustace had started from , and began the descent afresh , bearing to [his]73-eustace right . After that things seemed to be going better . [He]73-eustace went very cautiously , for [he]73-eustace could not see more than a yard ahead , and there was still perfect silence all around [him]73-eustace . It is very unpleasant to have to go cautiously when there is a voice inside [you]768-you saying all the time , “ Hurry , hurry , hurry . ”[73-eustace] For every moment the terrible idea of being left behind grew stronger . If [he]73-eustace had understood [Caspian]85-caspian and [the Pevensies]83-the pevensies at all [he]73-eustace would have known , of course , that there was not the least chance of [their]769-they doing any such thing . But [he]73-eustace had persuaded [himself]73-eustace that [they]769-they were [all fiends in human form]770-all fiends in human form .

“ At last ! ”[73-eustace] said [Eustace]73-eustace as [he]73-eustace came slithering down a slide of loose stones ( scree , [they]769-they call it ) and found [himself]73-eustace on the level . “ And now , where are those trees ? There is something dark ahead . Why , [I]73-eustace do believe the fog is clearing . ”[73-eustace]

It was . The light increased every moment and made [him]73-eustace blink . The fog lifted . [He]73-eustace was in [an utterly unknown valley]771-an utterly unknown valley and [the sea]250-the sea was nowhere in sight .

AT that very moment [the others]1949-the others were washing hands and faces in [the river]738-the river and generally getting ready for dinner and a rest . [The three best archers]775-the three best archers had gone up into [[the hills]776-the hills north of [the bay]521-the bay]777-the hills north of the bay and returned laden with a pair of wild goats which were now roasting over a fire . [Caspian]85-caspian had ordered a cask of wine ashore , strong wine of [Archenland]34-archenland which had to be mixed with water before [you]779-you drank it , so there would be plenty for all . The work had gone well so far and it was a merry meal . Only after the second helping of goat did [Edmund]79-edmund say , “ Where ’s that blighter [Eustace]73-eustace ? ”[79-edmund]

Meanwhile [Eustace]73-eustace stared round [the unknown valley]780-the unknown valley . It was so narrow and deep , and the precipices which surrounded [it]780-the unknown valley so sheer , that it was like a huge pit or trench . The floor was grassy though strewn with rocks , and here and there [Eustace]73-eustace saw black burnt patches like those [you]779-you see on the sides of [a railway embankment]781-a railway embankment in a dry summer .

About fifteen yards away from [him]73-eustace was a pool of clear , smooth water . There was , at first , nothing else at all in [the valley]782-the valley ; not an animal , not a bird , not an insect . The sun beat down and grim peaks and [horns of mountains]783-horns of mountains peered over [the valley]782-the valley ’s edge .

[Eustace]73-eustace realized of course that in the fog [he]73-eustace had come down [the wrong side of [the ridge]430-the ridge]785-the wrong side of the ridge , so [he]73-eustace turned at once to see about getting back . But as soon as [he]73-eustace had looked [he]73-eustace shuddered . Apparently [he]73-eustace had by amazing luck found the only possible way down — [a long green spit of land]787-a long green spit of land , horribly steep and narrow , with precipices on either side . There was no other possible way of getting back . But could [he]73-eustace do it , now that [he]73-eustace saw what it was really like ? [His]73-eustace head swam at the very thought of it .

[He]73-eustace turned round again , thinking that at any rate [he]73-eustace ’d better have a good drink from [the pool]788-the pool first . But as soon as [he]73-eustace had turned and before [he]73-eustace had taken a step forward into [the valley]782-the valley [he]73-eustace heard a noise behind [him]73-eustace . It was only a small noise but it sounded loud in that immense silence . It froze [him]73-eustace dead - still where [he]73-eustace stood for a second . Then [he]73-eustace slewed round [his]73-eustace neck and looked .

At the bottom of [the cliff]790-the cliff a little on [his]73-eustace left hand was a low , dark hole — [the entrance to a cave perhaps]791-the entrance to a cave perhaps . And out of this two thin wisps of smoke were coming . And the loose stones just beneath the dark hollow were moving ( that was the noise [he]73-eustace had heard ) just as if something were crawling in the dark behind [them]792-them .

Something was crawling . Worse still , something was coming out . [Edmund]79-edmund or [Lucy]80-lucy or [you]793-you would have recognized it at once , but [Eustace]73-eustace had read none of the right books . The thing that came out of [the cave]794-the cave was something [he]73-eustace had never even imagined — along lead - coloured snout , dull red eyes , no feathers or fur , a long lithe body that trailed on the ground , legs whose elbows went up higher than its back like a spider ’s cruel claws , bat ’s wings that made a rasping noise on the stones , yards of tail . And the lines of smoke were coming from its two nostrils . [He]73-eustace never said the word Dragon to [himself]73-eustace . Nor would it have made things any better if [he]73-eustace had .

But perhaps if [he]73-eustace had known something about [dragons]795-dragons [he]73-eustace would have been a little surprised at [this dragon]796-this dragon ’s behaviour . [It]796-this dragon did not sit up and clap [its]796-this dragon wings , nor did it shoot out a stream of flame from [its]796-this dragon mouth . The smoke from its nostrils was like the smoke of a fire that will not last much longer . Nor did [it]796-this dragon seem to have noticed [Eustace]73-eustace . [It]796-this dragon moved very slowly towards [the pool]788-the pool — slowly and with many pauses . Even in [his]73-eustace fear [Eustace]73-eustace felt that it was [an old , sad creature]798-an old , sad creature . [He]73-eustace wondered if [he]73-eustace dared make a dash for the ascent . But it might look round if [he]73-eustace made any noise . It might come more to life . Perhaps it was only shamming . Anyway , what was the use of trying to escape by climbing from a creature that could fly ?

[It]796-this dragon reached [the pool]788-the pool and slid [its]796-this dragon horrible scaly chin down over the gravel to drink : but before [it]796-this dragon had drunk there came from [it]796-this dragon a great croaking or clanging cry and after a few twitches and convulsions it rolled round on its side and lay perfectly still with one claw in the air . A little dark blood gushed from its wide - opened mouth . The smoke from its nostrils turned black for a moment and then floated away . No more came . this was [the brute]800-the brute ’s trick , the way it lured [travellers]801-travellers to [their]801-travellers doom . But [one]256-one could n’t wait for ever . [He]73-eustace took a step nearer , then two steps , and halted again . The dragon remained motionless ; [he]73-eustace noticed too that the red fire had gone out of its eyes . At last [he]73-eustace came up to it . [He]73-eustace was quite sure now that it was dead . With a shudder [he]73-eustace touched it ; nothing happened .

The relief was so great that [Eustace]73-eustace almost laughed out loud . [He]73-eustace began to feel as if [he]73-eustace had fought and killed the dragon instead of merely seeing [it]796-this dragon die . [He]73-eustace stepped over it and went to [the pool]788-the pool for [his]73-eustace drink , for the heat was getting unbearable . [He]73-eustace was not surprised when [he]73-eustace heard a peal of thunder . Almost immediately afterwards the sun disappeared and before [he]73-eustace had finished [his]73-eustace drink big drops of rain were falling .

The climate of [this island]717-this island was a very unpleasant one . In less than a minute [Eustace]73-eustace was wet to the skin and half blinded with such rain as [one]256-one never sees in [Europe]35-europe . There was no use trying to climb out of [the valley]782-the valley as long as this lasted . [He]73-eustace bolted for the only shelter in sight — [the dragon ’s cave]807-the dragon ’s cave . There [he]73-eustace lay down and tried to get [his]73-eustace breath .

[Most of [us]809-us know what [we]809-us should expect to find in [a dragon ’s lair]810-a dragon ’s lair]808-most of us know what we should expect to find in a dragon ’s lair , but , as [I]0-i said before , [Eustace]73-eustace had read only the wrong books . [They]811-they had a lot to say about exports and imports and governments and drains , but [they]811-they were weak on dragons . That is why [he]73-eustace was so puzzled at the surface on which [he]73-eustace was lying . Parts of it were too prickly to be stones and too hard to be thorns , and there seemed to be a great many round , flat things , and it all clinked when [he]73-eustace moved . There was light enough at [the cave]794-the cave ’s mouth to examine it by . And of course [Eustace]73-eustace found it to be what any of [us]809-us could have told [him]73-eustace in advance — treasure . There were crowns ( those were the prickly things ) , coins , rings , bracelets , ingots , cups , plates and gems .

[Eustace]73-eustace ( unlike [most boys]238-most boys ) had never thought much of treasure but [he]73-eustace saw at once the use it would be in [this new world]814-this new world which [he]73-eustace had so foolishly stumbled into through the picture in [[Lucy]80-lucy ’s bedroom]272-lucy ’s bedroom at [home]296-home . “ [They]811-they do n’t have any tax here , ”[73-eustace] [he]73-eustace said , “ And [you]2215-you do n’t have to give treasure to [the government]2216-the government . With some of this stuff [I]73-eustace could have quite a decent time here — perhaps in [Calormen]32-calormen . It sounds the least phoney of [these countries]2217-these countries . [I]73-eustace wonder how much [I]73-eustace can carry ? That bracelet now — those things in it are probably diamonds — [I’ll]73-eustace slip that on [my]73-eustace own wrist . Too big , but not if [I]73-eustace push it right up here above [my]73-eustace elbow . Then fill [my]73-eustace pockets with diamonds — that ’s easier than gold . [I]73-eustace wonder when this infernal rain ’s going to let up ? ”[73-eustace] [He]73-eustace got into a less uncomfortable part of the pile , where it was mostly coins , and settled down to wait . But a bad fright , when once it is over , and especially a bad fright following a mountain walk , leaves [you]817-you very tired . [Eustace]73-eustace fell asleep .

By the time [he]73-eustace was sound asleep and snoring [the others]1949-the others had finished dinner and became seriously alarmed about [him]73-eustace . [They]1949-the others shouted , “ [Eustace]73-eustace ! [Eustace]73-eustace ! Coo - ee ! ”[1949-the others] till [they]1949-the others were hoarse and [Caspian]85-caspian blew [his]85-caspian horn .

“ [He]73-eustace ’s nowhere near or [he]73-eustace ’d have heard that , ”[80-lucy] said [Lucy]80-lucy with a white face .

“ Confound [the fellow]2218-the fellow , ”[79-edmund] said [Edmund]79-edmund . “ What on earth did [he]2218-the fellow want to slink away like this for ? ”[79-edmund]

“ But [we]2219-we must do something , ”[80-lucy] said [Lucy]80-lucy . “ [He]2218-the fellow may have got lost , or fallen into a hole , or been captured by [savages]2220-savages . ”[80-lucy]

“ Or killed by wild beasts , ”[98-drinian] said [Drinian]98-drinian .

“ And a good riddance if [he]2218-the fellow has , [I]108-rhince say , ”[108-rhince] muttered [Rhince]108-rhince .

“ [Master Rhince]108-rhince , ”[89-reepicheep] said [Reepicheep]89-reepicheep , “ [you]108-rhince never spoke a word that became [you]108-rhince less . [The creature]2221-the creature is [no friend of [mine]89-reepicheep]2222-no friend of mine but [he]2221-the creature is of [the Queen]2223-the queen ’s blood , and while [he]2221-the creature is one of [[our]2219-we fellowship]2224-our fellowship it concerns [our]2219-we honour to find [him]2221-the creature and to avenge [him]2221-the creature if [he]2221-the creature is dead . ”[89-reepicheep]

“ Of course [we]2219-we ’ve got to find [him]2221-the creature ( if [we]2219-we can ) , ”[85-caspian] said [Caspian]85-caspian wearily . “ That ’s the nuisance of it . It means [a search party]2225-a search party and endless trouble . [Bother Eustace]73-eustace . ”[85-caspian]

Meanwhile [Eustace]73-eustace slept and slept — and slept . What woke [him]73-eustace was a pain in [his]73-eustace arm . The moon was shining in at [the mouth of [the cave]794-the cave]819-the mouth of the cave , and the bed of treasures seemed to have grown much more comfortable : in fact [he]73-eustace could hardly feel it at all . [He]73-eustace was puzzled by the pain in [his]73-eustace arm at first , but presently it occurred to [him]73-eustace that the bracelet which [he]73-eustace had shoved up above [his]73-eustace elbow had become strangely tight . [His]73-eustace arm must have swollen while [he]73-eustace was asleep ( it was [his]73-eustace left arm ) .

[He]73-eustace moved [his]73-eustace right arm in order to feel [his]73-eustace left , but stopped before [he]73-eustace had moved it an inch and bit [his]73-eustace lip in terror . For just in front of [him]73-eustace , and a little on [his]73-eustace right , where the moonlight fell clear on the floor of [the cave]794-the cave , [he]73-eustace saw a hideous shape moving . [He]73-eustace knew that shape : it was a dragon ’s claw . It had moved as [he]73-eustace moved [his]73-eustace hand and became still when [he]73-eustace stopped moving [his]73-eustace hand .

“ Oh , what a fool [I]73-eustace ’ve been , ”[73-eustace] thought [Eustace]73-eustace . “ Of course , [the brute]800-the brute had [a mate]2227-a mate and it ’s lying beside [me]73-eustace . ”[73-eustace]

For several minutes [he]73-eustace did not dare to move a muscle . [He]73-eustace saw two thin columns of smoke going up before [his]73-eustace eyes , black against the moonlight ; just as there had been smoke coming from the other dragon ’s nose before it died . This was so alarming that [he]73-eustace held [his]73-eustace breath . The two columns of smoke vanished . When [he]73-eustace could hold [his]73-eustace breath no longer [he]73-eustace let it out stealthily ; instantly two jets of smoke appeared again . But even yet [he]73-eustace had no idea of the truth .

Presently [he]73-eustace decided that [he]73-eustace would edge very cautiously to [his]73-eustace left and try to creep out of [the cave]794-the cave . Perhaps [the creature]2221-the creature was asleep — and anyway it was [his]73-eustace only chance . But of course before [he]73-eustace edged to the left [he]73-eustace looked to the left . Oh horror ! there was a dragon ’s claw on that side too .

[No one]1909-no one will blame [Eustace]73-eustace if at this moment [he]73-eustace shed tears . [He]73-eustace was surprised at the size of [his]73-eustace own tears as [he]73-eustace saw them splashing on to the treasure in front of [him]73-eustace . They also seemed strangely hot ; steam went up from them .

But there was no good crying . [He]73-eustace must try to crawl out from between the two dragons . [He]73-eustace began extending [his]73-eustace right arm . The dragon ’s fore - leg and claw on [his]73-eustace right went through exactly the same motion . Then [he]73-eustace thought [he]73-eustace would try [his]73-eustace left . The dragon limb on that side moved too .

Two dragons , one on each side , mimicking whatever [he]73-eustace did ! [His]73-eustace nerve broke and [he]73-eustace simply made a bolt for it .

There was such a clatter and rasping , and clinking of gold , and grinding of stones , as [he]73-eustace rushed out of [the cave]794-the cave that [he]73-eustace thought [they]826-they were both following [him]73-eustace . [He]73-eustace dare n’t look back . [He]73-eustace rushed to [the pool]788-the pool . The twisted shape of [the dead dragon lying in the moonlight]828-the dead dragon lying in the moonlight would have been enough to frighten [anyone]1930-anyone but now [he]73-eustace hardly noticed it . [His]73-eustace idea was to get into [the water]1834-the water .

But just as [he]73-eustace reached the edge of [the pool]788-the pool two things happened . First of all it came over [him]73-eustace like a thunder - clap that [he]73-eustace had been running on all fours — and why on earth had [he]73-eustace been doing that ? And secondly , as [he]73-eustace bent towards [the water]1834-the water , [he]73-eustace thought for a second that yet another dragon was staring up at [him]73-eustace out of [the pool]788-the pool . But in an instant [he]73-eustace realized the truth . The dragon face in the pool was [his]73-eustace own reflection . There was no doubt of it . [It]828-the dead dragon lying in the moonlight moved as [he]73-eustace moved : it opened and shut its mouth as [he]73-eustace opened and shut [his]73-eustace .

[He]73-eustace had turned into a dragon while [he]73-eustace was asleep . Sleeping on [a dragon]834-a dragon ’s hoard with greedy , dragonish thoughts in [his]73-eustace heart , [he]73-eustace had become [a dragon]834-a dragon [himself]73-eustace .

That explained everything . There had been [no two dragons beside [him]73-eustace in [the cave]794-the cave]836-no two dragons beside him in the cave . The claws to right and left had been [his]73-eustace own right and left claw . The two columns of smoke had been coming from [his]73-eustace own nostrils . As for the pain in [his]73-eustace left arm ( or what had been [his]73-eustace left arm ) [he]73-eustace could now see what had happened by squinting with [his]73-eustace left eye . The bracelet which had fitted very nicely on the upper arm of [a boy]838-a boy was far too small for the thick , stumpy foreleg of a dragon . It had sunk deeply into [his]73-eustace scaly flesh and there was a throbbing bulge on each side of it . [He]73-eustace tore at the place with [his]73-eustace dragon ’s teeth but could not get it off .

In spite of the pain , [his]73-eustace first feeling was one of relief . There was nothing to be afraid of any more . [He]73-eustace was a terror [himself]73-eustace and nothing in [the world]1877-the world but [a knight]1957-a knight ( and not all of those ) would dare to attack [him]73-eustace . [He]73-eustace could get even with [Caspian]85-caspian and [Edmund]79-edmund now But the moment [he]73-eustace thought this [he]73-eustace realized that [he]73-eustace did n’t want to . [He]73-eustace wanted to be [friends]841-friends . [He]73-eustace wanted to get back among [humans]842-humans and talk and laugh and share things . [He]73-eustace realized that [he]73-eustace was a monster cut off from [the whole human race]843-the whole human race . An appalling loneliness came over [him]73-eustace . [He]73-eustace began to see that [the others]1949-the others had not really been [fiends]845-fiends at all . [He]73-eustace began to wonder if [he]73-eustace [himself]73-eustace had been such a nice person as [he]73-eustace had always supposed . [He]73-eustace longed for [their]1949-the others voices . [He]73-eustace would have been grateful for a kind word even from Reepicheep .

When [he]73-eustace thought of this [the poor dragon that had been [Eustace]73-eustace]846-the poor dragon that had been eustace lifted up [its]846-the poor dragon that had been eustace voice and wept . [A powerful dragon crying its eyes out under the moon in [a deserted valley]848-a deserted valley]847-a powerful dragon crying its eyes out under the moon in a deserted valley is a sight and a sound hardly to be imagined .

At last [he]73-eustace decided [he]73-eustace would try to find [his]73-eustace way back to [the shore]455-the shore . [He]73-eustace realized now that [Caspian]85-caspian would never have sailed away and left [him]73-eustace . And [he]73-eustace felt sure that somehow or other [he]73-eustace would be able to make [people]207-people understand who [he]73-eustace was .

[He]73-eustace took a long drink and then ( [I]0-i know this sounds shocking , but it is n’t if [you]851-you think it over ) [he]73-eustace ate nearly all the dead dragon . [He]73-eustace was half - way through it before [he]73-eustace realized what [he]73-eustace was doing ; for , [you]851-you see , though [his]73-eustace mind was the mind of [Eustace]73-eustace , [his]73-eustace tastes and [his]73-eustace digestion were dragonish . And there is nothing [a dragon]834-a dragon likes so well as fresh dragon . That is why [you]851-you so seldom find more than one dragon in [the same county]853-the same county .

Then [he]73-eustace turned to climb out of [the valley]782-the valley . [He]73-eustace began the climb with a jump and as soon as [he]73-eustace jumped [he]73-eustace found that [he]73-eustace was flying . [He]73-eustace had quite forgotten about [his]73-eustace wings and it was a great surprise to [him]73-eustace — the first pleasant surprise [he]73-eustace had had for a long time . [He]73-eustace rose high into the air and saw innumerable mountain - tops spread out beneath [him]73-eustace in the moonlight . [He]73-eustace could see [the bay]521-the bay like a silver slab and [the Dawn Treader]382-the dawn treader lying at anchor and camp fires twinkling in [the woods]857-the woods beside [the beach]463-the beach . From a great height [he]73-eustace launched [himself]73-eustace down towards [them]859-them in a single glide .

[Lucy]80-lucy was sleeping very soundly for [she]80-lucy had sat up till the return of [the search party]860-the search party in hope of good news about [Eustace]73-eustace . [It]860-the search party had been led by [Caspian]85-caspian and had come back late and weary . [Their]860-the search party news was disquieting . [They]860-the search party had found no trace of [Eustace]73-eustace but had seen a dead dragon in [a valley]861-a valley . [They]860-the search party tried to make the best of it and [everyone]251-everyone assured [everyone else]863-everyone else that there were not likely to he more dragons about , and that one which was dead at about three o’clock that afternoon ( which was when [they]860-the search party had seen it ) would hardly have been killing [people]207-people a very few hours before .

“ Unless it ate [the little brat]2228-the little brat and died of [him]2228-the little brat : [he]2228-the little brat ’d poison anything , ”[108-rhince] said [Rhince]108-rhince . But [he]108-rhince said this under [his]108-rhince breath and [no one]1909-no one heard it .

But later in the night [Lucy]80-lucy was wakened , very softly , and found [the whole company]866-the whole company gathered close together and talking in whispers .

“ What is it ? ”[80-lucy] said [Lucy]80-lucy .

“ [We]860-the search party must all show great constancy , ”[85-caspian] [Caspian]85-caspian was saying . “ A dragon has just flown over the tree - tops and lighted on [the beach]463-the beach . Yes , [I]85-caspian am afraid it is between [us]860-the search party and [the ship]234-the ship . And arrows are no use against [dragons]795-dragons . And [they]795-dragons ’re not at all afraid of fire . ”[85-caspian]

“ With [[your]89-reepicheep Majesty]1838-your majesty ’s leave — ”[89-reepicheep] began [Reepicheep]89-reepicheep .

“ No , [Reepicheep]89-reepicheep , ”[305-the king] said [the King]305-the king very firmly , “ [you]89-reepicheep are not to attempt a single combat with it . And unless [you]89-reepicheep promise to obey [me]305-the king in this matter [I]305-the king ’ll have [you]89-reepicheep tied up . [We]860-the search party must just keep close watch and , as soon as it is light , go down to [the beach]463-the beach and give it battle . [I]305-the king will lead . [King Edmund]79-edmund will be on [my]305-the king right and [the Lord Drinian]98-drinian on [my]305-the king left . There are no other arrangements to be made . It will be light in a couple of hours . In an hour ’s time let a meal be served out and what is left of the wine . And let everything be done silently . ”[305-the king]

“ Perhaps it will go away , ”[80-lucy] said [Lucy]80-lucy .

“ It ’ll be worse if it does , ”[79-edmund] said [Edmund]79-edmund , “ because then [we]860-the search party sha n’t know where it is . If there ’s a wasp in [the room]237-the room [I]79-edmund like to be able to see it . ”[79-edmund]

The rest of the night wa dreadful , and when the meal came , though [they]868-they knew [they]868-they ought to eat , [many]621-many found that [they]868-they had very poor appetites . And endless hours seemed to pass before the darkness thinned and birds began chirping here and there and [the world]1877-the world got colder and wetter than it had been all night and [Caspian]85-caspian said , “ Now for it , [friends]841-friends . ”[85-caspian]

[They]868-they got up , all with swords drawn , and formed [themselves]868-they into a solid mass with [Lucy]80-lucy in the middle and [Reepicheep]89-reepicheep on [her]871-her shoulder . It was nicer than the waiting about and [everyone]251-everyone felt fonder of [everyone else]863-everyone else than at ordinary times . A moment later [they]868-they were marching . It grew lighter as [they]868-they came to the edge of [the wood]758-the wood . And there on [the sand]875-the sand , like a giant lizard , or a flexible crocodile , or a serpent with legs , huge and horrible and humpy , lay the dragon .

But when it saw [them]868-they , instead of rising up and blowing fire and smoke , [the dragon]876-the dragon retreated — [you]877-you could almost say it waddled — back into [the shallows of [the bay]521-the bay]878-the shallows of the bay .

“ What ’s it wagging its head like that for ? ”[79-edmund] said [Edmund]79-edmund .

“ And now it ’s nodding , ”[85-caspian] said [Caspian]85-caspian .

“ And there ’s something coming from its eyes , ”[98-drinian] said [Drinian]98-drinian .

“ Oh , ca n’t [you]85-caspian see , ”[80-lucy] said [Lucy]80-lucy . “ [It]876-the dragon ’s crying . Those are tears . ”[80-lucy]

“ [I]98-drinian should n’t trust to that , [Ma’am]97-ma’am , ”[98-drinian] said [Drinian]98-drinian . “ That ’s what crocodiles do , to put [you]97-ma’am off [your]97-ma’am guard . ”[98-drinian]

“ [It]876-the dragon wagged its head when [you]80-lucy said that , ”[79-edmund] remarked [Edmund]79-edmund . “ Just as if it meant No . Look , there it goes again . ”[79-edmund]

“ Do [you]85-caspian think it understands what [we]2236-us ’re saying ? ”[80-lucy] asked [Lucy]80-lucy .

[The dragon]876-the dragon nodded [its]876-the dragon head violently .

[Reepicheep]89-reepicheep slipped off [Lucy]80-lucy ’s shoulder and stepped to the front .

“ [Dragon]138-dragon , ”[89-reepicheep] came [his]89-reepicheep shrill voice , “ can [you]138-dragon understand speech ? ”[89-reepicheep]

[The dragon]876-the dragon nodded .

“ Can [you]138-dragon speak ? ”[876-the dragon]

[It]876-the dragon shook [its]876-the dragon head .

“ Then , ”[89-reepicheep] said [Reepicheep]89-reepicheep , “ it is idle to ask [you]138-dragon [your]138-dragon business . But if [you]138-dragon will swear friendship with [us]2236-us raise [your]138-dragon left foreleg above [your]138-dragon head . ”[89-reepicheep]

[It]876-the dragon did so , but clumsily because that leg was sore and swollen with the golden bracelet

“ Oh look , ”[80-lucy] said [Lucy]80-lucy , “ there ’s something wrong with [its]876-the dragon leg . [The poor thing]2237-the poor thing — that ’s probably what [it]876-the dragon was crying about . Perhaps it came to [us]2236-us to be cured like in [Androcles]139-androcles and the lion . ”[80-lucy]

“ Be careful , [Lucy]80-lucy , ”[85-caspian] said [Caspian]85-caspian . “ [It]876-the dragon ’s [a very clever dragon]2238-a very clever dragon but it may be [a liar]2239-a liar . ”[85-caspian]

[Lucy]80-lucy had , however , already run forward , followed by [Reepicheep]89-reepicheep , as fast as [his]89-reepicheep short legs could carry [him]89-reepicheep , and then of course [the boys]882-the boys and [Drinian]98-drinian came , too .

“ Show [me]80-lucy [your]89-reepicheep poor paw , ”[80-lucy] said [Lucy]80-lucy , “ [I]80-lucy might be able to cure it . ”[80-lucy]

[The dragon - that - had - been - [Eustace]73-eustace]883-the dragon - that - had - been - eustace held out its sore leg gladly enough , remembering how [Lucy]80-lucy ’s cordial had cured [him]73-eustace of sea - sickness before [he]73-eustace became [a dragon]834-a dragon . But [he]73-eustace was disappointed . The magic fluid reduced the swelling and eased the pain a little but it could not dissolve the gold .

[Everyone]251-everyone had now crowded round to watch the treatment , and [Caspian]85-caspian suddenly exclaimed , “ Look ! ”[85-caspian] [He]85-caspian was staring at the bracelet .

“ LOOK at what ? ”[79-edmund] said [Edmund]79-edmund .

“ Look at the device on the gold , ”[85-caspian] said [Caspian]85-caspian .

“ A little hammer with a diamond above it like a star , ”[98-drinian] said [Drinian]98-drinian . “ Why , [I]98-drinian ’ve seen that before . ”[98-drinian]

“ Seen it ! ”[85-caspian] said [Caspian]85-caspian . “ Why , of course [you]876-the dragon have . It is the sign of [a great Narnian house]2240-a great narnian house . This is the [Lord Octesian]103-the lord octesian ’s arm - ring . ”[85-caspian]

“ [Villain]140-villain , ”[89-reepicheep] said [Reepicheep]89-reepicheep to [the dragon]876-the dragon , “ have [you]876-the dragon devoured [a Narnian lord]2241-a narnian lord ? ”[89-reepicheep] But [the dragon]876-the dragon shook [his]876-the dragon head violently .

“ Or perhaps , ”[80-lucy] said [Lucy]80-lucy , “ this is [the Lord Octesian]103-the lord octesian , turned into a dragon — under an enchantment , [you]79-edmund know . ”[80-lucy]

“ It need n’t be either , ”[79-edmund] said [Edmund]79-edmund . “ [All dragons]2242-all dragons collect gold . But [I]79-edmund think it ’s a safe guess that [Octesian]103-the lord octesian got no further than [this island]717-this island . ”[79-edmund]

“ Are [you]876-the dragon [the Lord Octesian]103-the lord octesian ? ”[80-lucy] said [Lucy]80-lucy to the dragon , and then , when it sadly shook [its]876-the dragon head , “ Are [you]876-the dragon [someone enchanted]2244-someone enchanted — [someone human]2245-someone human , [I]876-the dragon mean ? ”[876-the dragon]

[It]876-the dragon nodded violently .

And then [someone]2007-someone said — [people]207-people disputed afterwards whether [Lucy]80-lucy or [Edmund]79-edmund said it first—“You’re not — not [Eustace]73-eustace by any chance ? ”[2007-someone]

And [Eustace]73-eustace nodded [his]73-eustace terrible dragon head and thumped [his]73-eustace tail in [the sea]250-the sea and [everyone]251-everyone skipped back ( some of [the sailors]275-the sailors with ejaculations [I]0-i will not put down in writing ) to avoid the enormous and boiling tears which flowed from [his]73-eustace eyes .

[Lucy]80-lucy tried hard to console [him]73-eustace and even screwed up [her]80-lucy courage to kiss the scaly face , and nearly [everyone]251-everyone said “ Hard luck ”[251-everyone] and several assured [Eustace]73-eustace that [they]251-everyone would all stand by [him]73-eustace and [many]621-many said there was sure to be some way of disenchanting [him]73-eustace and [they]251-everyone ’d have [him]73-eustace as right as rain in a day or two . And of course [they]251-everyone were all very anxious to hear [his]73-eustace story , but [he]73-eustace could n’t speak . More than once in the days that followed [he]73-eustace attempted to write it for [them]251-everyone on the sand . But , this never succeeded . In the first place [Eustace]73-eustace ( never having read the right books ) had no idea how to tell a story straight . And for another thing , the muscles and nerves of the dragon - claws that [he]73-eustace had to use had never learned to write and were not built for writing anyway . As a result [he]73-eustace never got nearly to the end before the tide came in and washed away all the writing except the bits [he]73-eustace had already trodden on or accidentaly swished out with [his]73-eustace tail . And all that [anyone]1930-anyone had seen would be something like this — the dots are for the bits [he]73-eustace had smudged

out [I]0-i WNET TO [SL EE]36-sl ee . . . RGOS AGRONS I MEAN [DRANGONS

CAVE]37-drangons cave CAUSE IT - WAS DEAD AND AWING SO HAR . . . WOKE UP AND COU . . . GET OFFF MI ARM OH BOTHER . . .

It was , however , clear to [everyone]251-everyone that [Eustace]73-eustace ’s character had been rather improved by becoming [a dragon]834-a dragon . [He]73-eustace was anxious to help . [He]73-eustace flew over [the whole island]898-the whole island and found [it]898-the whole island was all mountainous and inhabited only by wild goats and droves of wild swine . Of these [he]73-eustace brought back many carcasses as provisions for [the ship]234-the ship . [He]73-eustace was [a very humane killer]900-a very humane killer too , for [he]73-eustace could dispatch a beast with one blow of [his]73-eustace tail so that it did n’t know ( and presumably still does n’t know ) it had been killed . [He]73-eustace ate a few [himself]73-eustace , of course , but always alone , for now that [he]73-eustace was [a dragon]834-a dragon [he]73-eustace liked [his]73-eustace food raw but [he]73-eustace could never bear to let [others]2187-others see [him]73-eustace at [his]73-eustace messy meals . And one day , flying slowly and wearily but in great triumph , [he]73-eustace bore back to [camp]903-camp a great tall pine tree which [he]73-eustace had torn up by the roots in [a distant valley]904-a distant valley and which could be made into a capital mast . And in the evening if it turned chilly , as it sometimes did after the heavy rains , [he]73-eustace was a comfort to [everyone]251-everyone , for [the whole party]906-the whole party would come and sit with [their]906-the whole party backs against [his]73-eustace hot sides and get well warmed and dried ; and one puff of [his]73-eustace fiery breath would light the most obstinate fire . Sometimes [he]73-eustace would take [a select party]907-a select party for a fly on [his]73-eustace back , so that [they]906-the whole party could see wheeling below [them]906-the whole party [the green slopes]908-the green slopes , [the rocky heights]909-the rocky heights , [the narrow pit - like valleys]910-the narrow pit - like valleys and far out over [the sea]250-the sea to the eastward a spot of darker blue on the blue horizon which might be [land]395-land .

The pleasure ( quite new to [him]73-eustace ) of being liked and , still more , of liking [other people]224-other people , was what kept [Eustace]73-eustace from despair . For it was very dreary being [a dragon]834-a dragon . [He]73-eustace shuddered whenever [he]73-eustace caught sight of [his]73-eustace own reflection as [he]73-eustace flew over [a mountain lake]915-a mountain lake . [He]73-eustace hated the huge batlike wings , the saw - edged ridge on [his]73-eustace back , and the cruel , curved claws . [He]73-eustace was almost afraid to be alone with [himself]73-eustace and yet [he]73-eustace was ashamed to be with [the others]1949-the others . On the evenings when [he]73-eustace was not being used as a hot - water bottle [he]73-eustace would slink away from [the camp]917-the camp and lie curled up like a snake between the wood and the water . On such occasions , greatly to [his]73-eustace surprise , [Reepicheep]89-reepicheep was [his]73-eustace most constant comforter . [The noble Mouse]89-reepicheep would creep away from the merry circle at the camp fire and sit down by the dragon ’s head , well to the windward to be out of the way of [his]73-eustace smoky breath . There [he]73-eustace would explain that what had happened to [Eustace]73-eustace was a striking illustration of the turn of Fortune ’s wheel , and that if [he]73-eustace had [Eustace]73-eustace at [[his]73-eustace own house in [Narnia]2-narnia]918-his own house in narnia ( it was really a hole not [a house]706-a house and the dragon ’s head , let alone [his]73-eustace body , would not have fitted in ) [he]73-eustace could show [him]73-eustace more than a hundred examples of [emperors]920-emperors , [kings]277-kings , [dukes]922-dukes , [knights]923-knights , [poets]924-poets , [lovers]925-lovers , [astronomers]926-astronomers , [philosophers]927-philosophers , and [magicians , who had fallen from prosperity into the most distressing circumstances]928-magicians , who had fallen from prosperity into the most distressing circumstances , and of whom [many had recovered and lived happily ever afterwards]929-many had recovered and lived happily ever afterwards . It did not , perhaps , seem so very comforting at the time , but it was kindly meant and [Eustace]73-eustace never forgot it .

But of course what hung over [everyone]251-everyone like a cloud was the problem of what to do with [their]251-everyone dragon when [they]251-everyone were ready to sail . [They]251-everyone tried not to talk of it when [he]73-eustace was [there]226-there , but [he]73-eustace could n’t help overhearing things like , “ Would [he]73-eustace fit all along one side of [the deck]255-the deck ? And [we]251-everyone ’d have to shift all the stores to the other side down below so as to balance , ”[251-everyone] or , “ Would towing [him]73-eustace be any good ? ”[251-everyone] or “ Would [he]73-eustace be able to keep up by flying ? ”[251-everyone] and ( most often of all ) , “ But how are [we]251-everyone to feed [him]73-eustace ? ”[73-eustace] And [poor Eustace]73-eustace realized more and more that since the first day [he]73-eustace came on board [he]73-eustace had been [an unmitigated nuisance]932-an unmitigated nuisance and that [he]73-eustace was now a greater nuisance still . And this ate into [his]73-eustace mind , just as that bracelet ate into [his]73-eustace foreleg . [He]73-eustace knew that it only made it worse to tear at it with [his]73-eustace great teeth , but [he]73-eustace could n’t help tearing now and then , especially on hot nights .

About six days after [they]933-they had landed on [Dragon Island]38-dragon island , [Edmund]79-edmund happened to wake up very early one morning . It was just getting grey so that [you]934-you could see the tree - trunks if they were between [you]934-you and [the bay]521-the bay but not in the other direction . As [he]79-edmund woke [he]79-edmund thought [he]79-edmund heard something moving , so [he]79-edmund raised [himself]79-edmund on one elbow and looked about [him]79-edmund : and presently [he]79-edmund thought [he]79-edmund saw [a dark figure]936-a dark figure moving on the seaward side of the wood . The idea that at once occurred to [his]79-edmund mind was , “ Are [we]2247-we so sure there are [no natives]2248-no natives on [this island]717-this island after all ? ”[936-a dark figure] Then [he]79-edmund thought it was [Caspian]85-caspian — it was about the right size — but [he]79-edmund knew that [Caspian]85-caspian had been sleeping next to [him]79-edmund and could see that [he]85-caspian had n’t moved . [Edmund]79-edmund made sure that [his]79-edmund sword was in its place and then rose to investigate .

[He]79-edmund came down softly to the edge of the wood and [the dark figure]937-the dark figure was still there . [He]79-edmund saw now that it was too small for [Caspian]85-caspian and too big for [Lucy]80-lucy . [It]937-the dark figure did not run away . [Edmund]79-edmund drew [his]79-edmund sword and was about to challenge [the stranger]261-the stranger when [the stranger]261-the stranger said in a low voice , “ Is that [you]79-edmund , [Edmund]79-edmund ? ”[261-the stranger]

“ Yes . Who are [you]261-the stranger ? ”[79-edmund] said [he]79-edmund .

“ Do n’t [you]79-edmund know [me]471-the other ? ”[471-the other] said [the other]471-the other . “ It ’s [me]471-the other [Eustace]73-eustace . ”[471-the other]

“ By [jove]2250-jove , ”[79-edmund] said [Edmund]79-edmund , “ so it is . [[My]79-edmund dear chap]2251-my dear chap — ”[79-edmund]

“ Hush , ”[73-eustace] said [Eustace]73-eustace and lurched as if [he]73-eustace were going to fall .

“ Hello ! ”[79-edmund] said [Edmund]79-edmund , steadying [him]73-eustace . “ What ’s up ? Are [you]73-eustace ill ? ”[79-edmund]

[Eustace]73-eustace was silent for so long that [Edmund]79-edmund thought [he]73-eustace was fainting ; but at last [he]73-eustace said , “ It ’s been ghastly . [You]79-edmund do n’t know . . . but it ’s all right now . Could [we]2252-we go and talk somewhere ? [I]73-eustace do n’t want to meet [the others]1949-the others just yet . ”[73-eustace]

“ Yes , rather , anywhere [you]73-eustace like , ”[79-edmund] said [Edmund]79-edmund . “ [We]2252-we can go and sit on the rocks over there . [I]73-eustace say , [I]73-eustace am glad to see [you]73-eustace — er — looking [yourself]73-eustace again . [You]73-eustace must have had a pretty beastly time . ”[73-eustace]

[They]941-they went to the rocks and sat down looking out across [the bay]521-the bay while the sky got paler and paler and the stars disappeared except for one very bright one low down and near the horizon .

“ [I]73-eustace wo n’t tell [you]79-edmund how [I]73-eustace became a — a dragon till [I]73-eustace can tell [the others]1949-the others and get it all over , ”[73-eustace] said [Eustace]73-eustace . “ By the way , [I]73-eustace did n’t even know it was a dragon till [I]73-eustace heard [you]73-eustace all using the word when [I]73-eustace turned up here the other morning . [I]73-eustace want to tell [you]73-eustace how [I]73-eustace stopped being one . ”[73-eustace]

“ Fire ahead , ”[79-edmund] said [Edmund]79-edmund .

“ Well , last night [I]73-eustace was more miserable than ever . And that beastly arm - ring was hurting like anything — ”[73-eustace]

“ Is that all right now ? ”[73-eustace]

[Eustace]73-eustace laughed — a different laugh from any [Edmund]79-edmund had heard [him]73-eustace give before — and slipped the bracelet easily off [his]73-eustace arm . “ There it is , ”[73-eustace] [he]73-eustace said , “ and [anyone who likes]2255-anyone who likes can have it as far as [I]73-eustace ’m concerned . Well , as [I]73-eustace say , [I]73-eustace was lying awake and wondering what [on earth]2256-on earth would become of [me]73-eustace . And then — but , mind [you]73-eustace , it may have been all a dream . [I]73-eustace do n’t know . ”[73-eustace]

“ Go on , ”[79-edmund] said [Edmund]79-edmund , with considerable patience .

“ Well , anyway , [I]73-eustace looked up and saw the very last thing [I]73-eustace expected : a huge lion coming slowly towards [me]73-eustace . And one queer thing was that there was no moon last night , but there was moonlight where the lion was . So it came nearer and nearer . [I]73-eustace was terribly afraid of it . [You]73-eustace may think that , being [a dragon]834-a dragon , [I]73-eustace could have knocked any lion out easily enough . But it was n’t that kind of fear . [I]73-eustace was n’t afraid of it eating [me]73-eustace , [I]73-eustace was just afraid of it — if [you]73-eustace can understand . Well , it came close up to [me]73-eustace and looked straight into [my]73-eustace eyes . And [I]73-eustace shut [my]73-eustace eyes tight . But that was n’t any good because it told [me]73-eustace to follow it . ”[73-eustace]

“ [You]73-eustace mean it spoke ? ”[73-eustace]

“ [I]73-eustace do n’t know . Now that [you]73-eustace mention it , [I]73-eustace do n’t think it did . But it told [me]73-eustace all the same . And [I]73-eustace knew [I]73-eustace ’d have to do what it told [me]73-eustace , so [I]73-eustace got up and followed [it]2258-it . And it led [me]73-eustace a long way into [the mountains]752-the mountains . And there was always this moonlight over and round the lion wherever [we]2260-we went . So at last [we]2260-we came to [the top of [a mountain]2262-a mountain [I]73-eustace ’d never seen before]2261-the top of a mountain i ’d never seen before and on [the top of [this mountain]2264-this mountain]2263-the top of this mountain there was [a garden]2265-a garden — trees and fruit and everything . In the middle of [it]2265-a garden there was a well .[73-eustace]

“ [I]73-eustace knew it was a well because [you]73-eustace could see the water bubbling up from the bottom of it : but it was a lot bigger than [most wells]2266-most wells — like a very big , round bath with marble steps going down into [it]2265-a garden . The water was as clear as anything and [I]73-eustace thought if [I]73-eustace could get in there and bathe it would ease the pain in [my]73-eustace leg . But the lion told [me]73-eustace [I]73-eustace must undress first . Mind [you]73-eustace , [I]73-eustace do n’t know if [he]73-eustace said any words out loud or not .[73-eustace]

“ [I]73-eustace was just going to say that [I]73-eustace could n’t undress because [I]73-eustace had n’t any clothes on when [I]73-eustace suddenly thought that dragons are snaky sort of things and snakes can cast [their]2267-their skins . Oh , of course , thought [I]73-eustace , that ’s what the lion means . So [I]73-eustace started scratching [myself]73-eustace and [my]73-eustace scales began coming off all over [the place]2268-the place . And then [I]73-eustace scratched a little deeper and , instead of just scales coming off here and there , [my]73-eustace whole skin started peeling off beautifully , like it does after an illness , or as if [I]73-eustace was a banana . In a minute or two [I]73-eustace just stepped out of it . [I]73-eustace could see it lying there beside [me]73-eustace , looking rather nasty . It was a most lovely feeling . So [I]73-eustace started to go down into [the well]2269-the well for [my]73-eustace bathe .[73-eustace]

“ But just as [I]0-i was going to put [my]0-i feet into the water [I]0-i looked down and saw that they were all hard and rough and wrinkled and scaly just as they had been before . Oh , that ’s all right , said [I]0-i , it only means [I]0-i had another smaller suit on underneath the first one , and [I]0-i ’ll have to get out of it too . So 1 scratched and tore again and this underskin peeled off beautifully and out [I]0-i stepped and left it lying beside the other one and went down to the well for [my]0-i bathe .[0-i]

“ Well , exactly the same thing happened again . And [I]0-i thought to [myself]0-i , oh dear , how ever many skins have [I]0-i got to take off ? For [I]0-i was longing to bathe [my]0-i leg . So [I]0-i scratched away for the third time and got off a third skin , just like the two others , and stepped out of it . But as soon as [I]0-i looked at [myself]0-i in [the water]1834-the water [I]0-i knew it had been no good .[0-i]

“ Then the lion said”—but[0-i] [I]0-i do n’t know if it spoke—“You will have to let [me]0-i undress [you]0-i . ”[0-i] [I]0-i was afraid of [his]0-i claws , [I]0-i can tell [you]943-you , but [I]0-i was pretty nearly desperate now . So [I]0-i just lay flat down on [my]0-i back to let [him]0-i do it .

“ The very first tear [he]0-i made was so deep that [I]0-i thought it had gone right into [my]0-i heart . And when [he]0-i began pulling the skin off , it hurt worse than anything [I]0-i ’ve ever felt . The only thing that made [me]0-i able to bear it was just the pleasure of feeling the stuff peel off . [You]943-you know — if [you]943-you ’ve ever picked the scab off a sore place . It hurts like billy - oh but it is such fun to see it coming away . ”[0-i]

“ [I]79-edmund know exactly what [you]79-edmund mean , ”[79-edmund] said [Edmund]79-edmund .

“ Well , [he]0-i peeled the beastly stuff right off — just as [I]0-i thought [I]0-i ’d done it [myself]0-i the other three times , only [they]2271-they had n’t hurt — and there it was lying on the grass : only ever so much thicker , and darker , and more knobbly - looking than the others had been .
